div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly..as under for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Oriental Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Saturday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUTH (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, calling fortnightly at LARNACA (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardahelles, Gallipoli anf Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sedan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

Mail Steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sina), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden. For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Fort Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK and SON (Eygypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIEA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: ENGLAND IN EGYPT.
div.p: In a review of Mr. Blunt’s latest book on Egypt, the “Manchester Guardian” suggested that Sir Charles Dilke was accused by Mr. Blunt “of bartering Egypt to Gam- betta’s financial friends in exchange Tor the commercial treaty with France upon which our Under-Secretary had set his heart” Sir Charles replies to this statement in the issue
of our contemporary of last Thursday, and states that there is no foundation for the suggestion:

On many occasions, he continues, the late Sir Ellis Ahsmead-Bartlett introduced the allegation into his. speeches in the House of Commons and into articles written by him for “England” and other journals: In reply ing to him in the House I set forth the facts as I now repeat them.

Without offering an opinion on the historical problem whether the Joint Note was or was not a necessary or a prudent consequence of the Cave mission, the Goschen mission, and the dual control, I have to say that it was the act of the Cabinet before I became a member of that body, and that, owing to my absence in Paris as chairman of the Royal Commission for the commercial treaty with France, I did not—as I otherwise should have done—hear of the negotiation until it was complete. Egyptian affairs were not discussed between Mr. Gambetta and myself. So far was I, moreover, from having “set my heart” upon the negotiation of a commercial treaty that it is known to my colleagues who were with me in Paris, all of whom are living, as is the then head of the Commercial Department, through whom we communioated with the Foreign Office and the Board of Trade upon the details, that I had from the first a disinclination to make a treaty and a preference for a most-favoured-nation arrangement This I hoped would follow after we had obtained by discussion all the improvements in the French tariff as to the advantages of which we thought we could convince the Government of France.

In the House of Commons I went out of my way during the continuance of the prolonged negotiations to declare that I would not sign a treaty which did not fulfil two main conditions—(a) that it should be a further improvement on the whole over the improved state of things which had followed the reductions of tariff later than those of the Cobden Treaty, and (b) also should not sacrifice any principal branch of British trade.
The first condition was fulfilled as a result of the negotiations, but the second, though accomplished as regards the best Sheffield cutlery and certain other constituents of our export trade.

The great prolongation of the negotiations undoubtedly led our colleagues of the French High Commission under two successive French Administrations to believe that we intended to sign a treaty. It was publicly admitted on both sides that we were in a position to sign a treaty which would be on the whole defensible. The extraordinary deration of the negotiations were caused by the fact that most of the Continental Powers were negotiating with France “behind” us, as the phrase goes. With their representatives we were also in daily relations. As concessions were made for which certain interests in France pressed and which concerned chiefly British trade, our French colleagues granted these in their Swiss and other negotiations. At the last, when they signed treaties with Switzerland and several other Powers, the French Government came' face to facevyrith the necessity for either giving us all these favourable changes of their tariff in a most favoured-nation law or treating us in an unfriendly fashion, which there was nothing to warrant. For some time it was thought that our refusal to sign would ;be visited upon our trade by such extended to us for a short time by Spain. Wisdom, however, prevailed in the French Legislature, and (after I had finally broken off the negotiations, and, the other treaties having been signed by France, a pause had followed) a law was passed with singular rapidity by which there was extended to us that most-favoured-nation treatment which has continued to the present time ; although the lowest scale of duty has been raised for all Powers in the intervening years. At no time was the Egyptian policy of either Cabinet allowed to have a bearing upon the commercial relation of the Powers.

div.head: Drowned.
div.p: A native child, aged 6 years, was drowned yesterday in one of the reservoirs of Ali Bey Tcrgoman’s mill at Boulac.

div.head: The Municipal Palace.
div.p: The question of the erection of a new Municipal Palace for Alexandria has been postponed until the autumn.

div.head: Fatal Scorpion Sting.
div.p: A little native girl, named Nahiba, who was stung by a scorpion in Rue Korn el Cheikh Salama, has died from the effects.

div.head: A Founding.
div.p: An abandoned child was discovered yesterday in Sharia Abdin. It has been taken -ini&o a private hospital, where it will be well eared for.

div.head: Carriage Accident.
div.p: On Wednesday evening towards 7 o’clock a Vasrieh tram overturned a carriage in Sharia ’lot bey, completely wrecking it and seriously injuring the driver, who was immediately transferred to hospital in a desperate condition.

div.head: Kanka Asyluna.
div.p: The construction ot the new lunatic asylum at Kanka will be commenced immediately and will be actively carried on. The total cost of the establishment to the Government is estimated at about L.E. 110,000.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: The following particulars of bubonic plague throughout Egypt were recorded during the past 24 hours: — 1 admission and 1 death in hospital at Samallout and 1 death at Daman- hour outside of hospital. 15 patients remain under treatment.

div.head: Coptle Bazar Tragedy.
div.p: The Aix Tribunal has acquitted le Bihan, junior, who was accused with his father of the murder of the Chauffeur Leporcq, which took placein their house two months ago. As already reported Bihan senior was acquitted a month ago.

div.head: Public Health Department.
div.p: Acting on the suggestion of the Director General of this Department, the Ministry of the Interior has appointed Mohained Effendi Amin Chakib as veterinary surgeon of the 4th class, and Jean Gallat as dispenser of the 2nd class to the hospital at Port Said, dating from 13th June.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: Acting on the suggestion of the Director General of this Department, the Ministry of the Interior has appointed Mohained Effendi Amin Chakib as veterinary surgeon of the 4th class, and Jean Gallat as dispenser of the 2nd class to the hospital at Port Said, dating from 13th June.

div.head: Accidents.
div.p: A spirit lamp being carelessly handled is again responsible for serious injuries received by Mohamed Afifieficier, at Boulac yesterday evening at about 9 o’clock. It appears that he thoughtlessly placed the lamp close to an open can of petrol which exploded, causing great damage. While crossing the railway line near Helouan, Borai Farraga was run over by a train belonging to the Delta Light Railways Death was instantaneous. A man was discover ed by the police at Old Cairo yesterday lying in the roadway in a moribund condition, suffering from terrible wounds in the back and chest. On the way to hospital the injured man died, and as yet no clue as to his identity or the cause of his injuries is forthcoming. A post mortem examination will be held at the hospital.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham’s Weekly Report Liverpool, June 27.
The demand for Spot Egyptians still continues small, and quite of a retail character, being scarcely sufficient to test prices. Quota tions are nominally 3/16d plb. down.
In Futures a small business has been done, and the following are the latest values June 10.24 Sep. 10.21 Dec. 10.14 Mar. 10.11 July 10.22 Oct. 10.20 Jan. 10.11 Aug 10.23 Nov. 10.18 Feb. 10.11

American Futures. The Market this week has l>een fairly active, and prices experienced first a sharp decline, and later a more important recovery. To-day’s closing values are, for the current month 3 \ points, the other Old Crop positions 6@ 7j points, and the various New Crop positions 7@ 10 points higher than those of last Thursday.

The decline was chiefly due to continued favorable crop reports and an absence of any speculative support ; the subsequent recovery in values was due to reaction, manipulation ; and professional support on the “Bull” side aided by some sensational reports as to the unfavorable prospects of the crop in face of the official highly improved weatherconditions. No one at present can form any intelligent forecast of the market because there is no publio element of any weight operating in any of the markets. There are supposed to be influential forces at work here which control the Old Crop positions, and another set operation upon the same lines in New York and New Orleans with the usual professional traders who ride upon the backs of these cliques. div.head: OPENING OF THE CASSA.
div.p: RESPONSIBILITY OF DIRECTORS.

The Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio will open definitely to-morrow morning. Possibly the bank may open for a few minutes this evening, in order that the technical legal necessity for avoiding the lapse of fifteen days after shutting the doors should be complied with. The Syndicate to advance the £ 300,000 has been formed. The liquidation is being carried on under the auspices of the National Bank of Egypt. This bank has appointed two liquidators who will be the executive officers of the liquidation. They will be members of a committee of four persons. The other two members of this committee are being appointed by the board of directors of the Cassa di Sconto. In the case of there being an equality of votes between the four members of this committee, the casting vote will be in the hands of a delegate of the Governor or Sub.Governor of the National Bank of Egypt.

div.head: TROUBLES IN CAIRO.
div.p: A number of firms in Cairo, mostly in the Mousky quarter of the capital, are in difficulties, but the centre of gravity in these cases is in Manchester. The difficulties can be tided over if patience is exercised until the cotton crop has been financed and money begins to come in after October. It is not reasonable to expect that in the middle of summer, arrangements should be brought to an abrupt termination.

div.head: ENGLISH COMPANIES IN EGYPT.
div.p: The excellent resume on the liability of Directors under the Companies (English) Act of 1900, whicli appeared in your issue of yesterday and its applicability to non-British Directors domiciled abroad, will be appreciated by those who have followed the efforts of your journal to throw some light on this obscure question.

The main points at issue appear to be whether the British Consular Court in Egypt is possessed of the power tx try cases against non- British Directors, or whether that jurisdiction lies with the mixed Tribunals, and whether a criminal action can be maintained in either court.

As regards the last point, it may be very seriously doubted if the British Consular Courts would in any case assume the responsibility ot trying even British subjects in criminal cases arising under the Companies Act of 1900. When one remembers the difficulties which had to be surmounted in England before the then Attorney General could be induced to take action against Whittaker Wright, and the numerous failures which have resulted from actions in England against Directors since the date in which the last Act came into force, one can hardly anticipate any keenness on the part of the British Consulate in Egypt to assume a liability which it may very reasonably be pleaded lies with the High Courts of Justice in England.
It would appear, however, that civil actions for damages against the Directors will have an equally good hearing in either the British Consular Courts or in the mixed Tribunals.

The law under which the Companies we are discussing are formed, enacts that each Director must inter-alia either himself, or through his agent, have signed and filled with the Registrar of Companies his consent in writing, to act as a Director. The Director is therefore bound by the Articles of Association which is registered with the memorandum: and it is difficult to understand how he can in any Court of Law plead any exemption from his contract. One may feel safe therefore, in leaving the decision with the mixed Tribunals.

Several companies registered in England have recently on the insistance of shareholders in Egypt transferred the direction to this country ; and it may reasonably'be supposed that before consenting to such transfer the English Directors have taken counsel’s opinion 0" Jihe subject, and have safeguarded the in terests of their sharedolders in every way.

Therefore in the words of your contributor we may confidently anticipate that the non British Director in Egypt “will not be able to avail himself of the benefit of British law and at the same time, by a lotal technicality, be enabled to rid himself of all his obligations thereunder.

div.head: LONDON OPINION.
div.p: (GaMttw’e Spmoiai S+rvloo.)
LANCASHIRE AND THE EGYPTIAN CRISIS.
London, Friday.

The opinion in financial circles in the City is that Sir Ernest Cassel deserves to be heartily congratulated on having come to the rescue of the banking community of Egypt, and of having saved them from what might have been a serious calamity by having finally brought the negotiations for a voluntary liquidation of the Cassa di Sconto to a successful conclusion. These negotiations were completed yesterday and a group of financiers have placed a quarter of a million at the disposal of the Cassa for the purpose of enabling the bank to meet its current liabilities and thus enabling the liquidation to be carried out gradually:' Tlie consequence is that the settlement recently foreshadowed is now assured.

Although the recent bank suspension at Alexandria has not seriously affected either the export trade in raw cotton or the import trade in piece-goods there has been some anxiety in Manchester about the financial position in Egypt It is known that land speculation has been freely carried on for some months past, and the fact that several banks have recently opened new branches at Cairo and Alexandria has probably led to the granting of credits which in other circumstances would have been unobtainable. The “Manchester Guardian” learns, however, upon good financial authority that the situation is now well in hand and that there need be no apprehension of any unfavourable developments such as would gravely affect Manchester trade interests.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: THE BUILDING OF A CITY.

div.head: REGULATIONS FOR CONSTRUCTION.
div.p: By Roberts Williams F. R. I. B. A.
III.

In my last paper, mention was made of a rumour that the Municipality was about to make a regulation to the effect that all persons intending to build were to deposit plans at the office of the Municipality and to obtain the sanction of the authorities before beginning to build. I have just had placed in my hand confirmation of that rumour, a copy of the regulation which it is intended should remain in force until the promulgation of definite regular tions. That is to say, we are to have a kind of stop-gap for something definite in a conntry where indefiniteness reigns paramount How long shall we have to wait none can tell.

Six years ago I enquired at the Municipality for the^Alexandria building regulations. 1 was politely informed that there were none, but that they had been in consideration for one or two years. Later on when I had matured mypl&hs for a building, I enquired again but was told that the regulations were still in abeyance. But a move is now made for which I am sure the citizens of Alexandria and in particular the regular architectural practi- tioneere should, be thankful. The gist of the proposed interim regulations is as follows :—

No buildings are to be erected and no enlargement, heightening, rearrangement or repairs or any work whatsoever is to be undertaken to existing buildings withio the area of the city of Alexandria, before plans are submitted and approved of by the Municipality.
The following requisitions are made.

list.item: Complete sections both vertical and horizontal with elevations ot the intended building.

div.p: When all these documents, which will entail considerable expense to the proprietors are handed to the Municipality in duplicate, it will, in 15 days (not 15 weeks or months) but expeditiously in 15 days (dans le dklai de 15 jours) make known its approval or otherwise, and herein comes the troublesome point. The London building act only requires a notice of two days and the applicant has not to wait for approval. Judging from what I have seen of building in Alexandria during the last six years it can safely be said that the majority of buildings are erected with little or no calculations as to their strength.

Formerly a building of three storeys was a high one in Alexandria, now they are of five or six storeys and I have heard off the possibility of the erection of a ten storey building. Recent calamitous accidents have proved that the Alexandrian mason is not acquainted with the workmanship required to ensure the stability of high, thick walls. He is deficient in the knowledge of bond. Reinforced concrete or bkton armk and steel construction specially for floor and weight bearing structures, are coming much into vogue, these and the taller buildings now being built demand the setting forth of an absolute minimum as to thickness ot walls, strength of joists etc. There is also the question of mortar, which, together with bond, is of the greatest importance in good building; but on these points the proposed regulations are silent.

Asking for plans before setting forth general regulations as to building, is certainly, as I said before, putting the cart before the horse. How are the officers of the Municipality to decide whether our plans are correct, say, as to the matter of thickness of walls ? Have they secret codes, or will they make their decisions in a haphazard fashion \If they have a code —a means of deciding the strength of struc tures—then nothing could be easier than to draw up a general regulation in accordance therewith. This is thrown out as a suggestion, as, so far as I understand, this proposed regulation has not yet received the sanction of publication in the Official Journal.
As to an interim regulation the following is also offered as a suggestion.

list.item: Every intending builder to furnish a notice on a printed form giving (a) the position of his building (b) the number of floors and height (c) name and address of the builder.

div.p: This is all that is generally required in London with its population of five .millions. The following are the regulations as to notices of the London building act

“Every building notice shall state the situation, area, height, number of storeys and intended use of the building or structure and the number of buildings or structures, if more than one and the particulars of the proposed work and the name and address of the person giving the notice and those of the owner then in possession, and of the occupier of the building or structure or of its site or intended site.
All works in progress at the same time to, in, or on fhe same building or structure may be included in one building notice.”
No plans are asked for save in the matter of publio buildings or special structures.
As the Municipality here is the sanitary as well as the building authority (in London the building and sanitary authorities aTe separate) the following may be added to the building regulation.

list.item: A block plan to be submitted showing the position of the building, the adjacent streets, the drains and connection with public sewers.

div.p: The plan might be drawn on a space reserved for it on the notice paper.
But while one agrees to the issuing of tentative regulations, no time should be lost in formulating and publishing regulations as to construction etc.
The following is the text of the regulations.

div.head: ARTICLE PREMIER.
div.p: Les mesures et prescriptions suivantes se- ront appliqukes k titre transitoire en attendant la promulgation d’un rkglement dkfinitif oon- cemaut les routes ainsi que le eontrdle des constructions dans la Ville d’Alexandrie.

Nul nepourra construire, agrandir, surkle- ver, rkconforter on rkparer dans le pkrimktre de la ville d’Alexandrie k quelque titre ou dans quelque Kmite que ce soit des maisons, edifices, mure de cldture, balcons, perrons, trottoire ou tout ouvrage, avant que les plans de l’ouvrage projetk ne soient sonmis A 1a Municipality et approuvks par elle et avant d'a- voir re^n du Service du Tanzim l’antorisation de l’alignement en ce qui eoncerne les ouvra- ges bordant la voie publique.
Les dessins k presenter en double expedition par les interests devront comprendre :

list.item: Les plans du rez-de-chausske et divers Stages avec elevations et coupes k 1’kchelle de un pour cent.
Un plan d’ensemble de ^emplacement k construire, des voies qui le bordent on l’avoisi- nent, ainsi que des dispositions de drainage k rechelle de un pour mille.
Les plans des solivages et toitures k l’echelle de un pour cent.
Des details cotes k l’kchelle de un pour dix de tontes autres parties essentielles de constructions, (piliere, colonnes, consoles et sections des fondations).

div.p: Les intkressks anront en outre k soumet- tre k la Municipality le cahier des charges relatif aux travaux k executor.

L’Administration devra, dans le delai de 15 jours k partir de la presentation des dessins et cahier des charges ci-dessus, ma- nifester son approbation et deiivrer en consequence la roksa de construction et d’aligne- meut Au cks oh ces dessins et cahier des charges n’auraient pas ete agrees, la Municipality devra daus le rnkme delai en faire part aux interesses et leur communiquer les observation^ qu’elle croira devoir formuler.
Aucnne modification au plan approuve par la Municipality on an cahier des charges ne pourra £tre apportee sans l’agrement ecrit de cette dernikre.

La Municipality pourra retirer dans ce cas lautorisationetemp6cher touts continuation des travaux.

div.head: EGYPTIAN WEATHER.
div.p: The Survey Department of the Ministry of Finance has issued the following report on the weather for last month:—

Throughout the month the weather has been settled and fine. The barometer was somewhat abo\e normal at most stations in Egypt and the Sudan, but slightly below at European stations in the Eastern Mediterranean. Temperature was rather low at most stations of our area. As usual in this month there has been no rainfall in Egypt On the Sudan plains the rain appears to have been in defect, and at Suakin it failed altogether.

On the first of the month temperature was somewhat high, but with a rise of pressure it fell a little until another fall of pressure gave an increase of temperature again upon the 4th. Conditions were then normal until another fall of pressure on the 10th. and 11th. gave warm dry southerly winds. The temperatures experienced were not, however, excessive and regular Khamsin conditions were not recorded except at Suez. From the 12th to the end ot the month Egyptian weather conditions were steady. The highest temperature of the month at Egyptian stations occurred on the 4th or the 11th and the lowest about the 9th.
In the Sudan regular summer conditions are established. At Khartoum on the 2nd there was a violent “habub” which is stated by newspaper reports to have done considerable damage in the town.
The Blue Nile and the Sobat were late in beginning their permanent rise and are still below their normal levels. It appears that the Nile Flood of this year will be somewhat behind time.

div.head: SERIOUS CONFLAGRATION.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
Damanhonr, Friday.
A terrible conflagration broke out yesterday at Abou Khousha. The entire village was burnt and four persons perished in the flames.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner “Khephren” arrived thia morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers Philippeville and Malta with passengers, mails general cargo.

div.head: LOCAL CRICKET MATCH.
div.p: A most exciting cricket match was played yesterday afternoon at Mustapha between a team from the ships in harbour, amnged by Capt Runton, and a team of the Dublin Fasi- liers, captained by Colour Serjeant Byrne. The sailors started rather badly, Tappet being dismissed for a duck, and Fisher and Purvis only put on 6 and 4 respectively, but the tail wagged merrily and useful scores were made by Captains Waterworth, Ronton, Findlay, and Bell, all of whom played a very steady game. The play of the Dublin Fusiliers was even throughout, though the team was somewhat weakly constituted. With the last man in the Fusiliers drew level with the 70 of Captain Runton’s team and the excitement was intense. A fairly fast ball from Teppet found Wylleye on the spot, and it was well driven towards the boundary, but* unfortunately for the latter and his side*. Captain Findlay was there, and the ball was firmly secured in his hands, thus bringing a good match to a dead heat.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: GYMKHANA.

A Gymkhana is being arranged by several members of the Alexandria Sporting Club for to-morrow afternoon, commencing at 3 p.m., the programme of which will be as follows :— Bending Race, Lloyd Lindsay, Polo Match; Hack Scurry; Stick and Ball Polo; PigSticking; Tentpeggiug. Members are aocordingly invited to take part.
For each event prizes will be distributed. Post Entries. Entrance P.T. 10. As the polo ground will be used for the Gymkhana the golf course will not be open tomorrow afternoon.

div.head: MACLEAN's CAPTURE.
div.p: SULTAN’S REPRESENTATIVE’S
ASSISTANCE.
Tangier, July 4.

The British Legation here is doing all that is possible to Secure the release of Sir H. Maclean. The Sultan’s representative is assisting heartily. The Legation has received a letter from Sir H. Maclean stating that he is well and is being kindly treated. (Reuter)
Tangier, July 4
The Khmes tribe are keeping an eye on Kaid Maclean and Raisuli with a view to liberating the former, or sharing the ransom with the latter. (Havas)

div.head: LORD SELBORNE'S MEMORANDUM.
div.p: ADVANTAGES of a federation.
London, July 4.

Lord Selborne has issued an important memorandum forcibly urging the advantages of a federation. He declares that the decision cannot be postponed in view of the intimate interdependency of the Colonies regarding railways, customs, and the native questions. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SECRET HISTORY.
div.p: Mr. Wilfrid Blunt’s Secret History of the Occupation of Egypt, is full of passages of extreme local interest. The following is an extract from his journal of 1887, January 31. Cairo.—Called on Princess Nazli She is at least as clever as she is pretty. Her conversation would be brillant in any society in the world. She told us a great deal that interested us about Arabi, for whom she bad, and I am glad to see still has, a great culte, talking of his singleness of mind and lamenting his overthrow. He was not a good enough soldier, she 3aid, and has too good a heart. These were his faults. If he had been a violent man like my grandfather, Mohemet Ali, he would have taken Tewfik and all of us to the Citadel and cut our heads off—and he would have been now happily reigning, or if he could have got the Khedive to go on honestly with him he would have made a great king of him. Arabi was the first Egyptian Minister who made tjie Europeans obey him. In his time at least the Mohammedans held up their heads and the Greeks, and Italians did not dare transgress the law. I have told Tewfik this more than once. Now there is nobody to keep order. The Egyptians alone are kept under by the police and the Europeans do as they like.

div.head: MUZZLING THE PRESS.
div.p: Sir Auckland Colvin knew how to muzzle the Press. Mr. Blunt writes : —

It will perhaps be as well to explain here the way in which the London Press and especially Reuter’s News Agency was at this time manipulated officially at Cairo, and made subservent to the intrigues of diplomacy.

Very few London newspapers had any regular correspondent in Egyp£ the “Times” and the “Pall Mall Gazette” being, as far as I know, the only two that were thus provided. Both, as far as politics were concerned, were practically in the hands of Sir Auckland Colvin, the English financial controller, an astute Indian official, with the traditions of Indian diplomacy strongly developed in his political practice. He had some experience of journalism, having been connected with the “Pioneer” in India, an Anglo-Indian Journal of pronounced imperialistic type with which he was still in correspondence. He was also Morley’s regular correspondent in the “Pall Mall Gazette” and had through him the ear of the Government.

The importance of this unavowed connection will be seen later when he made it his business to bring about English intervention. Lastly, on all important diplomatic matters he inspired the “Times” whose regular correspondent, Scott, depended on him lor his information. With regard to Reuter and Havas, the telegraphic agencies, both were heavily sub- ventioned by the Anglo French Financial control, receiving £1,000 a year each, charged on the thin resources of the Egyptian Budget. Reuter especially was the servant and mouthpiece of the English Agency and the telegrams despatched to London were under Mallet’s censorship. This sort of manipulation of the organs of public ’ news in the interests of our diplomacy, exists in nearly all the c&pitals where our agents reside and is a potent instrument for misleading the home public. The influence is not as a rule exercised by any direct payment, but by favour given in regard to secret and valuable information, and also largely, by social amenities. In Egypt it has always within my knowledge been supreme, except at moments of extreme crisis when the body of special press correspondents at Cairo or Alexandria has been too numerous to be kept under official control. In ordinary times our officials have had complete authority both as to what news should be sent to London, and what news, received from London, should be published in Egypt,' It is very necessary that this, the true condition of things should be steadily borne in mind by historians when they consult the newspaper files of these years in search of information.

div.head: EGYPT AND GLASDSTONE.
div.p: An exceptionally interesting passage showing Gladstone’s views of Egypt is quoted from an article contributed by that politician to the “Nineteenth Century” in 1877. Gladstone writes:—“Our first site in Egypt” he writes “be it by larceny or be it by emption, will be the almost certain egg of a North African Empire that will grow and grow till another Victoria and another Albert, titles ofthe lake sources of the White Nile, will come within our borders and till we. finally join hands across the equator with Natal and Cape Town, to say nothing of the Transvaal and the Orange River on the South of Abyssinia or Zanzibar,^to be swallowed by way of viaticum on our journey and then, with a great empire in each of the four quarters of the world—we may be territorially content but less than ever at our ease.”Mr. Gladstone’s views of Sir Auckland Colvin, and Sir E. Malet’s work in Egypt are thus noticed in the report of an interview between Mr. Blunt and the Liberal statesman :“I delivered all Arabi’s messages about the slave trade and the other projects of reform, and -then went on to explain Colvin’s position and Malet’s. He said almost, pathetically, “What can we do ?” They are esteemed public servants and have received honours for their work in Egypt. He insisted upon fhe word honours.

div.head: MR. BLUNTS IMPORTANCE.
div.p: Mr. Blunt is fully convinced of his enormous importance. The italicised sentences given below are delightful samples cf his
coneeit :—

With the regular press correspondents he knew how to deal, but he could not deal with us, who were independent writers, or exercise the smallest censorship on our opinions. There was an end therefore to the close intimacy I had, up to that point* in spite of small disagreements, had with the agency. This was unfortunate as it threw Mallet, who always needed to loan on some one stronger than himself into other and less conciliatory hands.

On the 31st of January, the very day of the change of Ministry at Paris I find a note to the effect that I went into Cairo and saw Colvin and had a remarkable conversation with him. This has become or great historical importance throngh subsequent events for it marks the date within a few days of the change of temper of the English Financial control, and with it of our diplomacy towards Egyptian nationalism, and also fixes upon Colvin, what is indeed his due, the chief responsibility of the rupture which afterwards through his oon triving came about

div.head: WOLSELY AND EGYPT.
div.p: We extract the following from an account of Mr. Blunt’s interview with Lord Wolseley :—

He volunteered the information that he had been consulted two or three times during the winter with a view to immediate occupation He assured me, however, that nobody wanted, to intervene, that the Occupation of Egypt would be most unpopular with the Army, and that he himself should he very sorry to have to go there. He would far rather the Egyptians should disband their army and trust to European protection, but I told him I could not advise them to do that, and that people were not often attacked who really meant fighting. He said well of course there is no such thing as honour in war, and if there were really any question of fighting, they ought not to trust us more than other people.” He then talked about the various military routes to Cairo, Bonaparte’s by the left bank of the Nile, and especially the desert way between the Suez Canal and the Delta, so that I felt pretty sure that if troops were landed it would be on that side.But I was careful to give him no information which could be of the least use to him, and 1 only laughed when he half seriously asked ipe whether I would go with him and show him the way if it came, to a campaigne.

My impression of Wolseley was of a good smart soldier, an Irishman with a rough touch of brogue, good humoured and I should fancy enterprising. But he does not impress me as a man of genius —what Napoleon used to call a “g&idral a dix mille hommes.” It is worth noting that in writing to Sheikh Moham ed Abdou, through my secretary Sabunji, soon after this conversation, I alluded to the danger there might be, in case of intervention, of their being attacked from the Ismailia side, and I believe it was in consequence of this hint that the lines of Tel-el-Kebir were begun to be traced by Arabi’s order.

div.head: EXCAVATION OF MEMPHIS.
div.p: APPEAL FOR FUNDS.

An important letter, signed by Sir Robert Hensley, Sir William Richmond, Professor Mahaffy, and Professor Ernest Gardner, appealing for assistance for the British School of Archaeology in Egypt in the work of excavating Memphis, appeared in the press last week:—

Sir,—One of the greatest capitals in the ancient world has been left untouched in its dust, although the ground is visited by thousands of tourists every year. Memphis whose history extends over the whole coarse of Egyptian civilization, has never yet been explored. It contained the finest school of Egyptian art, and in antiquity and wealth it was unrivalled. But most of it has gradu ally passed under the plough, and to res cue what yet remains is most needful before it further disappears. Great national undertakings, as of France in the clearing of Delphi, or of Germany at Olympia, oan never be done under our form of government, which ignores such intellectual conquests. Scientific research by England is mainly matter of public association; and it is to the public that the British School of Archaeology in Egypt must look for the needful support of the excavations which it is going to undertake (by permission of the Egyptian Government) at Memphis.

The vast temple of Ptab, the temple of Isis, the sumptuous dwelling of the sacred Apis, the rich temple of Aphrodite in the Phoenician and foreign quarter — all these were the celebrated sights of Memphis in the Greek age and beneath the ruins of some of these must lie the monuments of the beginning of the Egyptian kingdom, from Mcmes onward. The sites of these temples are plainly visible amid the mounds. The area of them is equal to the whole of Karnak, the southern capital of the land. It is known definitely where the search must be made . for the statues, the sculptures, and the records of the oldest capital of Egypt. To dearths temple sites is estimated to cost about year for 15 or 20 years/This,

we hope, may he possible as a national enterprise ; and, as halt of the sculptures discovered will be granted by the Egyptian Government, should reward any nation that undertakes the work. The greater scope, of the complete clearance of all the ancient capital, would require about half a million, and can hardly be hoped for unless supported by one of the great masters of industry or finance. But we trust that the ordinary British method of subscription—from the' traditional guinea upward—will enable us at least to clear the metropolitan temples of Egypt, and not to feel ashamed in view of the splendid labour of excavation accomplished by other countries. To be obliged to invite the assistance of foreign support in this task would prevent our reaping the reward of the gratuitous labour given by Professor Flinders Petrie and his helpers.

The secretary of the British School, at University College, London (Gower-street), will give any further information, at the exhibition of the discoveries of the present year, July 1 to 27, held at the college, where also the publications given to subscribers may be seen. We remain, Sir, yours obediently,
W.B. RICHMOND.
J.P. MAHAFFY.
EA. GARDNER.
R.M. HENSLEY (Chairman)

div.head: EGYPTIAN LIFE AND SCENERY.
div.p: LONDON ART EXHIBITIONS.
(Prom a Special Correspondent).
London, Junb28.

The joint exhibition of pictures on Egyptian subjects by Miss Nellie Hadden and Miss McCracken at Maclean’s Gallery has already received notice in these columns ; and this week we have had the pleasure of inspecting the works of two other artists who have approached the subjects of Egyptian life and scenery from very widely diverging points of view.

The few weeks spent by Miss Sybil Dowie this winter in Helouan were her first introduction to the land of splendid colouring and atmosphere ; and the work she has done during that sport period is a distinct departure from her former efforts, which ‘have been almost invariably devoted to portraiture. Her education in art includes several years spent in Paris where at one time she studied at the Gulian school under Bougereau and again with Lazar. She has already made a certain reputation for her portraits in both oils and pastels, and has had various of her works accepted by the Royal Academy and the Salone, while one occupies a place in the permanent gallery of Bolton’s Hall.

Unlike most other Egyptian aitists, Miss Dowie has chosen the mediums of both oil and pastel in her present exhibition of “sketches Df Egypt” which has occupied one of the rooms of the Dord Gallery, and has recorded her impressions in a bolder and more impressionist style than we have been accustomed to. Her pastels are sombre and quiet in colouring and are mostly confined to interiors and bazaar scenes ; but her sketches in oil, if lacking in detail, are very spontaneous records of sunshine and colour. Seeing that Miss Dowie’s stay in Egypt last winter was only of six weeks’ duration, her exhibition is in every way creditable to her, and if she sees her way to extending her acquaintance with the country which has impressed her so favourably, we may hope in future to count her among the valuable exponents of its many beauties.

The work of Mr.W.Tyndal is of a very different genre. Already he ranks among the first of our Egyptian artists, and his knowledge of the country and its history adds a deeper zest to many of his pictures beyond their mere beauty of form and colouring. So minute and perfect is the detail of some of the wall paintings de* lineated by him, that their history lies like an open book before those who have eyes to see, and yet the intricate detail is given with so much subtlety and sense of proportion that it never detracts from the effect of the main scheme. His long stay in the neighbourhood of Thebes this winter has resulted in many a picture of the wonderful tombs and temples there, as well as at Karnak and Luxor; and he has also included in his present collection some very fine and marvellously proportioned studies of the temple of Abu Simbel. There are also some wonderful reproductions of wall paintings:—the “Isis suckling Horus” from Abydos, and others from the Temple of Amada, and the Tomb of Nacht at Thebes. Very interesting too are the coloured casts of Senseneb and Aahmes from the Temple of Hatehepsu, which have only been procured with the greatest of care and infinite trouble.

Mr. Tyndale’s love 'of architecture and mas- tery of perspective are shown to their best in his painting of many of the native streets of Cairo and elsewhere. No other artist has a more pleasing sense of colour and effect, Done can reproduce more delicately the*luminous shadows, the varied colouring, and the fine stone carving and musharabieh work which gives these streets such character. Notable for these qualities are his pictures taken in the Bab el Zuela and the Khaleeg, while others of the same sort are entitled “The Sheik’s House” and “After the midday Prayer.”

Early in the forthcoming autumn, Mr. Tyndale hopes to place before the public, his book entitled “Below the Cataracts” which will be all the more valuable for including some sixty reproductions of his pictures.

From Liverpool we hear most favourable accounts of the success of Mr. A. 0. Lam- plough’s exhibition at Messrs. Giryndley and Palmer’s Galleries. His pictures are so well known in Cairo circles that it is hardly necessary to dwell further on the properties which have made them so popular. Those to whom the land of the Pharaohs is a sealed book may learn much of its beauties as seen by Mr. Lamplough’s eyes; and those who know and love the land are quick to appreciate his efforts and to realize their value. Mr. Lainp- longh intends bringing his pictures to London in July, when doubtless he will still further increase bis reputation.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: THE NEW COMMAND.
A Cairo vernacular organ makes the following interesting comments on the new command •—

The last thing heard of the Duke of Connaught in connection with Egypt was extremely interesting. It was rumoured that as Commander-in-Chiet of the British Garrisons in the Mediterranean Stations be has made up bis mind to live in Egypt during the term of his command. According to official arrangements the central office for this military command will be at Malta, where the Dnke is not a stranger. But we have been repeatedly told that his Royal Highness prefers Alexandria to Valetta and will make our great seaport his head quarters. Egyptians will be glad to see a Royal Duke among the distinguished rulers in their land.

Some of our readers, however, look upon the new arrangement with the Duke of Connaught as Commander in Chief, from another point of view. To certain minds • the mere fact that Egypt is now included in matters military with Malta and Gibraltar and Cyprus in this new arrangement, and that no separate command is left for Egypt, means that thq British Government now take it for granted that Egypt and Malta are both possessions of England in the same way. Whether the new command was created to convey tbis meaning or for other purposes, some of those who interpret actions and events are emphatic in their ateejfction that England has definitely, hut stealthily, counted Egypt among her dominions beyond the sea. Other events and proceedings of recent date are equally eloquent in pointing out the same moral, but no absolute conviction can be claimed. By all means let a Royal Duke come and stay here. Let a firm and powerful Government be established on a permanent footing, for Egypt is tired ot a temporary arrangement.

div.head: Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

PUBLIC CALL-OFFICES : Cairo, Central Office, Opera Square, and New Bar; Helouan, Central Office, Maison Purvis ; Alexandria, St Mark’s Buildings, Egyptian Bar, I. Castelli & Co.; Ramleh, Central Office. San Stefano Casino 30.4.906
